This is primarily a review of concepts related to vectors that are important for E&M. If a topic covered is unfamiliar, please review the basic concepts first. Khan Academy has a comprehensive introduction to vectors that is recommended.

1 Vector Notation

The general form of a 2-dimensional vector is

A = A x x ^ + A y y ^ \mathbf{A} = A_x\hat{\mathbf{x}} + A_y\hat{\mathbf{y}} A=Ax​x^+Ay​y^​

Variations on notation include the equivalent equations

A = A x ı ^ + A y ȷ ^ and A = ⟨ A x , A y ⟩ \mathbf{A} = A_x\hat{\boldsymbol{\imath}} + A_y\hat{\boldsymbol{\jmath}}\quad\text{and}\quad \mathbf{A} = \langle A_x, A_y \rangle A=Ax​^+Ay​^​andA=⟨Ax​,Ay​⟩

The vector A \mathbf{A} A can be viewed as the sum of the two vectors A x x ^ A_x\hat{\mathbf{x}} Ax​x^ and A y y ^ A_y\hat{\mathbf{y}} Ay​y^​. On the left-hand side of the following figure, the two components of A \mathbf{A} A are shown (assuming the scalar quantities A x A_x Ax​ and A y A_y Ay​ are both positive). In the middle, the sum of these components is shown.

By definition, the magnitude of A \mathbf{A} A is given by the Pythagorean formula

A = ∣ A ∣ = A x 2 + A y 2 A = |\mathbf{A}| = \sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2} A=∣A∣=Ax2​+Ay2​​

As indicated in this equation, A A A and ∣ A ∣ |\mathbf{A}| ∣A∣ are equivalent – often one is used instead of the other for clarity of presentation. Another representation for the magnitude of A \mathbf{A} A uses the dot product – A = A ⋅ A A =\sqrt{\mathbf{A}\cdot\mathbf{A}} A=A⋅A​.

Common error: Referring to ∣ A ∣ |\mathbf{A}| ∣A∣ as “The absolute value of A \mathbf{A} A”. The absolute value operator operates on a scalar, e.g., − 12.1 -12.1 −12.1. When used with a vector, the vertical bars mean “The magnitude of A \mathbf{A} A”. Both the absolute value and magnitude operations yield a positive scalar, but their calculation is different. The absolute value operation is to simply drop a negative sign. The magnitude operation requires the use of the Pythagorean formula.

If θ \theta θ is defined to be the angle from the x x x-axis with positive angles counterclockwise,

A x = A cos ⁡ θ and A y = A sin ⁡ θ A_x = A\cos\theta\quad\text{and}\quad A_y=A\sin\theta Ax​=AcosθandAy​=Asinθ

Writing the previous equations as

A x = ∣ A ∣ cos ⁡ θ and A y = ∣ A ∣ sin ⁡ θ A_x = |\mathbf{A}|\cos\theta\quad\text{and}\quad A_y=|\mathbf{A}|\sin\theta Ax​=∣A∣cosθandAy​=∣A∣sinθ

makes it clear that the sign of A x A_x Ax​ (or A y A_y Ay​) is due to the cos ⁡ θ \cos\theta cosθ (or sin ⁡ θ \sin\theta sinθ) term and not the term that multiplies it. Although A A A is a positive number because it is a magnitude, writing it as ∣ A ∣ |\mathbf{A}| ∣A∣ may make this point clearer.

Elimination of A A A from A x = A cos ⁡ θ A_x = A\cos\theta Ax​=Acosθ and A y = A sin ⁡ θ A_y=A\sin\theta Ay​=Asinθ gives

sin ⁡ θ cos ⁡ θ = A y A x or tan ⁡ θ = A y A x \frac{\sin\theta}{\cos\theta} = \frac{A_y}{A_x}\quad\text{or} \quad \tan\theta = \frac{A_y}{A_x} cosθsinθ​=Ax​Ay​​ortanθ=Ax​Ay​​

which is expected based on the diagram on the right of the previous figure.

1.1 References

Every introductory physics and calculus textbook has a comprehensive introduction to vectors. The reader is encouraged to use them for review. Khan Acadamy has a comprehensive introduction to vectors that is recommended.

Several unique perspectives on vectors include

  • The Feynman Lectures on Physics, which introduces and motivates the use of vectors by the fact that many laws of physics have invariance (symmetry) under translation and rotation. In the Vector Addition/Subtraction section of these notes, I motivate the use of vectors by noting that they simplify geometric calculations for which one would usually use Pythagorean’s theorem and the Law of Cosines (which is derived from the Pythagorean theorem) multiple times.

  • The Math Centre’s Introduction to Vectors gives several examples of proving geometrical relationships using vectors (mid-point theorem and an unnamed theorem).

1.2.2 Computing magnitude and angle

Draw A = − 1 x ^ + y ^ \mathbf{A}=-1\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \hat{\mathbf{y}} A=−1x^+y^​ and compute A A A and θ \theta θ, where θ \theta θ is as defined as the angle with respect to the x x x–axis with positive θ \theta θ corresponding to counterclockwise rotation.

1.2.3 Notation

The conventional definition of a vector, its components, and the angle is A = A x x ^ + A y y ^ \mathbf{A} = A_x\hat{\mathbf{x}} + A_y\hat{\mathbf{y}} A=Ax​x^+Ay​y^​, where A x = A cos ⁡ θ A_x = A\cos\theta Ax​=Acosθ, A y = A sin ⁡ θ A_y=A\sin\theta Ay​=Asinθ, and θ \theta θ is as defined as the angle with respect to the x x x–axis with positive θ \theta θ corresponding to counter-clockwise rotation.

Let θ ′ \theta' θ′ be defined as the angle with respect to the y y y–axis with positive θ ′ \theta' θ′ corresponding to counterclockwise rotation.

1. Write the equations for A x ′ A'_x Ax′​ and A y ′ A'_y Ay′​ in terms of θ ′ \theta' θ′.

2. If A = 1 A=1 A=1 and θ ′ = 4 5 ∘ \theta'=45^\circ θ′=45∘, find A x A_x Ax​, A y A_y Ay​, A x ′ A'_x Ax′​, and A y ′ A'_y Ay′​.

1.2.4 Notation

If A = ( x − y ) x ^ − y y ^ \mathbf{A} = (x-y)\hat{\mathbf{x}}-y\hat{\mathbf{y}} A=(x−y)x^−yy^​,

1. Compute ∣ A ∣ |\mathbf{A}| ∣A∣

2. Compute A A A

3. What, if possible, are the values of x x x and y y y that will give A < 0 A < 0 A<0?

4. What, if possible, are the values of x x x and y y y that will give 9 0 ∘ ≤ θ ≤ 27 0 ∘ 90^\circ \le \theta \le 270^\circ 90∘≤θ≤270∘?

  • A \mathbf{A} A and B \mathbf{B} B;

  • the unit vectors x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ and y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^​.

Draw and label

  • C = A + B \mathbf{C}=\mathbf{A}+\mathbf{B} C=A+B

  • D = A − B \mathbf{D}=\mathbf{A}-\mathbf{B} D=A−B

  • E = − A + B \mathbf{E}=-\mathbf{A}+\mathbf{B} E=−A+B, and

  • F = − A − B \mathbf{F}=-\mathbf{A}-\mathbf{B} F=−A−B.

Compute, in terms of x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ and y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^​ and numbers

  • C \mathbf{C} C and ∣ C ∣ |\mathbf{C}| ∣C∣

  • D \mathbf{D} D and ∣ D ∣ |\mathbf{D}| ∣D∣

  • E \mathbf{E} E and ∣ E ∣ |\mathbf{E}| ∣E∣

  • F \mathbf{F} F and ∣ F ∣ |\mathbf{F}| ∣F∣

3 Unit Vectors

A unit vector is a vector with “unit length” (meaning a length of unity, that is, 1).

The “unit” in “unit vector” means “unit length”; perhaps confusingly, unit vectors do not have a unit (such as meters) – they are dimensionless.

A unit vector associated with an arbitrary vector is obtained by dividing it by its magnitude. We indicate that it is a unit vector by using a hat. So a vector such as r = r x x ^ + r y y ^ \mathbf{r}=r_x\hat{\mathbf{x}} + r_y\hat{\mathbf{y}} r=rx​x^+ry​y^​ that has magnitude r = ∣ r ∣ = r x 2 + r y 2 r = |\mathbf{r}|=\sqrt{r_x^2 + r_y^2} r=∣r∣=rx2​+ry2​​ has an associated unit vector

r ^ = r r = r x x ^ + r y y ^ r = r x r x 2 + r y 2 x ^ + r y r x 2 + r y 2 y ^ \hat{\mathbf{r}} = \frac{\mathbf{r}}{r}=\frac{r_x\hat{\mathbf{x}} + r_y\hat{\mathbf{y}}}{r}=\frac{r_x}{\sqrt{r_x^2 + r_y^2}}\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \frac{r_y}{\sqrt{r_x^2 + r_y^2}}\hat{\mathbf{y}} r^=rr​=rrx​x^+ry​y^​​=rx2​+ry2​​rx​​x^+rx2​+ry2​​ry​​y^​

The unit vector points in the same direction as the vector used to create it because

tan ⁡ θ = r ^ y r x ^ = r y / r r x / r =   r y r x \tan\theta = \frac{\hat{r}_y}{\hat{r_x}} = \frac{r_y/r}{r_x/r}= \ \frac{r_y}{r_x} tanθ=rx​^​r^y​​=rx​/rry​/r​= rx​ry​​

3.1 Example

One reason that unit vectors are useful is that they allow us to make statements of the form: “An object is 11 meters along the direction of r \mathbf{r} r”.

Suppose r = ( 10  m ) x ^ + ( 20  m ) y ^ \mathbf{r}=(10\text{ m})\hat{\mathbf{x}}+(20\text{ m})\hat{\mathbf{y}} r=(10 m)x^+(20 m)y^​. To find a position that is 11 meters along the direction of r \mathbf{r} r, first find a vector of length 1 that is in the direction of r \mathbf{r} r, namely, its unit vector. Then multiply this unit vector by 11 meters.

r = ( 10  m ) 2 + ( 20  m ) 2 = 500  m r = \sqrt{(10\text{ m})^2 + (20\text{ m})^2} = \sqrt{500}\text{ m} r=(10 m)2+(20 m)2​=500​ m

r ^ = r r = ( 10  m ) x ^ + ( 20  m ) y ^ 500  m = x ^ + 2 y ^ 5 \hat{\mathbf{r}}=\frac{\mathbf{r}}{r}=\frac{(10\text{ m})\hat{\mathbf{x}} + (20\text{ m})\hat{\mathbf{y}}}{\sqrt{500}\text{ m}}=\frac{\hat{\mathbf{x}} + 2\hat{\mathbf{y}}}{\sqrt{5}} r^=rr​=500​ m(10 m)x^+(20 m)y^​​=5​x^+2y^​​

Notice how the units of meters ( m \text{m} m) canceled - a unit vector is dimensionless (we also use the term “unit–less” for “dimensionless”).

It was claimed that a unit vector has a length of 1. This can be verified:

∣ r ^ ∣ = ( 1 5 ) 2 + ( 2 5 ) 2 = 1 ✓ |\hat{\mathbf{r}}| = \sqrt{\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{2}{\sqrt{5}}\right)^2}=1\quad\checkmark ∣r^∣=(5​1​)2+(5​2​)2​=1✓

We can now form a vector for the position of the object that is 11 meters along the direction of r \mathbf{r} r:

( 11  m )   r ^ = ( 11  m ) ( 1 5 x ^ + 2 5 y ^ ) (11\text{ m})\,\hat{\mathbf{r}}=(11\text{ m})\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{5}}\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \frac{2}{\sqrt{5}}\hat{\mathbf{y}}\right) (11 m)r^=(11 m)(5​1​x^+5​2​y^​)

Note that a unit vector can be associated with any type of vector, not just position vectors.

3.2 Problems

3.2.1   

If A = − 3 x ^ + 4 y ^ \mathbf{A} = -3\hat{\mathbf{x}} + 4\hat{\mathbf{y}} A=−3x^+4y^​, find A ^ \mathbf{\hat{A}} A^, find the unit vector in the direction of A \mathbf{A} A.

3.2.2   

If r = x x ^ + y y ^ \mathbf{r}=x\hat{\mathbf{x}} + y\hat{\mathbf{y}} r=xx^+yy^​ and r ′ = x ′ x ^ + y ′ y ^ \mathbf{r}' = x'\hat{\mathbf{x}} + y'\hat{\mathbf{y}} r′=x′x^+y′y^​,

1. Find R ^ \boldsymbol{\hat{\mathcal{R}}} R^, the unit vector in the direction of R ≡ r − r ′ \boldsymbol{\mathcal{R}} \equiv \mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}' R≡r−r′.

2. Choose numbers for ( x , y ) (x,y) (x,y) and ( x ′ , y ′ ) (x',y') (x′,y′), sketch r \mathbf{r} r and r ′ \mathbf{r}' r′, and verify that the direction of R ^ \boldsymbol{\hat{\mathcal{R}}} R^ is consistent with the unit vector R \boldsymbol{\mathcal{R}} R that you computed.

4 Curvilinear Unit Vectors

Thus far, only the cartesian unit vectors x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^, y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^​, and z ^ \hat{\mathbf{z}} z^ have been considered. There are many other coordinate systems, each of which has their own set of unit vectors. The most common curvilinear coordinate systems are cylindrical and spherical.

4.1 Cylindrical

4.1.1 Definitions and Notation

The unit vectors for cylindrical coordinates, s ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} s^, ϕ ^ \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} ϕ^​, and z ^ \hat{\mathbf{z}} z^, are shown in the following figure at an arbitrary point P P P. Note that the conventional symbol for the radial coordinate in cylindrical is either ρ \rho ρ or r r r, but s s s is used in the following figure. In this course, ρ \rho ρ is used for charge density, and r r r is used for the spherical radial coordinate, so s s s will be used instead.

  • s ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} s^ is always parallel to the x x x– y y y plane and points radially outward,

  • z ^ \hat{\mathbf{z}} z^ always points parallel to the z z z–axis in the direction of increasing z z z, and

  • ϕ ^ \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} ϕ^​ is perpendicular to s ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} s^ and z ^ \hat{\mathbf{z}} z^ and points in the direction of increasing ϕ \phi ϕ.

The relationship between cartesian and cylindrical coordinates is

x = s cos ⁡ ϕ y = s sin ⁡ ϕ z = z x = s\cos\phi\qquad y=s\sin\phi\qquad z=z x=scosϕy=ssinϕz=z

The relationship between cartesian and cylindrical unit vectors is

s ^ = cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ ϕ ^ = − sin ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ ϕ y ^ z ^ = z ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} = \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}}\qquad \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} = -\sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}}\qquad \hat{\mathbf{z}}=\hat{\mathbf{z}} s^=cosϕx^+sinϕy^​ϕ^​=−sinϕx^+cosϕy^​z^=z^

4.1.2 Example - Writing Cylindrical Unit Vectors with Cartesian Coordinates and Unit vectors

s ^ = cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} = \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}} s^=cosϕx^+sinϕy^​ can be written in terms of cartesian coordinates and unit vectors by using

cos ⁡ ϕ = x s = x x 2 + y 2 \displaystyle \cos\phi = \frac{x}{s}=\frac{x}{\sqrt{x^2+y^2}} cosϕ=sx​=x2+y2​x​ and sin ⁡ ϕ = y s = y x 2 + y 2 \displaystyle \sin\phi = \frac{y}{s}=\frac{y}{\sqrt{x^2+y^2}} sinϕ=sy​=x2+y2​y​. Substitution gives s ^ = x x 2 + y 2 x ^ + y x 2 + y 2 y ^ \displaystyle \hat{\mathbf{s}} = \frac{x}{\sqrt{x^2+y^2}}\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \frac{y}{\sqrt{x^2+y^2}}\hat{\mathbf{y}} s^=x2+y2​x​x^+x2+y2​y​y^​

As a check, compute ∣ s ^ ∣ |\hat{\mathbf{s}}| ∣s^∣ and verify that it is 1 1 1.

4.1.3 Example - Drawing Cylindrical Unit Vectors

Draw a sketch showing

  1. A = s ^ + ϕ ^ \mathbf{A} = \hat{\mathbf{s}} + \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} A=s^+ϕ^​ at the position ( s , ϕ , z ) = ( 1 , 0 , 0 ) (s,\phi,z) = (1,0,0) (s,ϕ,z)=(1,0,0) and

  2. A = ϕ ^ \mathbf{A} = \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} A=ϕ^​ at the position ( s , ϕ , z ) = ( 1 , π / 2 , 0 ) (s,\phi,z) = (1,\pi/2,0) (s,ϕ,z)=(1,π/2,0).

Answer:

4.1.4 Example - Computing Cylindrical Coordinates Given Cartesian Coordinates

Given the position ( x , y , z ) = ( 1 , 1 , 1 ) (x,y,z)=(1,1,1) (x,y,z)=(1,1,1), compute ( s , ϕ , z ) (s,\phi,z) (s,ϕ,z).

Answer: Substitution of x = 1 x=1 x=1 into x = s cos ⁡ ϕ x=s\cos\phi x=scosϕ and y = 1 y=1 y=1 into y = s sin ⁡ ϕ y=s\sin\phi y=ssinϕ gives 1 = s cos ⁡ ϕ 1=s\cos\phi 1=scosϕ and 1 = s sin ⁡ ϕ 1=s\sin\phi 1=ssinϕ. Elimination of s s s gives tan ⁡ ϕ = 1 \tan\phi = 1 tanϕ=1, so ϕ = π / 2 \phi=\pi/2 ϕ=π/2. Squaring x = s cos ⁡ ϕ x=s\cos\phi x=scosϕ and y = s sin ⁡ ϕ y=s\sin\phi y=ssinϕ and adding gives x 2 + y 2 = s 2 cos ⁡ 2 ϕ + s 2 sin ⁡ 2 ϕ = s 2 x^2+y^2=s^2\cos^2\phi+s^2\sin^2\phi=s^2 x2+y2=s2cos2ϕ+s2sin2ϕ=s2, so s 2 = 2 s^2=2 s2=2 and s = 2 s=\sqrt{2} s=2​. From x = s cos ⁡ ϕ x=s\cos\phi x=scosϕ, it follows that ϕ = 4 5 ∘ \phi=45^\circ ϕ=45∘. Finally, z z z in cylindrical is the same as z z z in cartesian, so z = 1 z=1 z=1.

4.2 Spherical

4.2.1 Definitions and Notation

The unit vectors for spherical at an arbitrary point P P P are shown in the following figure (From danfleisch.com).

  • r ^ \hat{\mathbf{r}} r^ is in the direction of a line drawn from the origin to P P P,

  • ϕ ^ \boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} ϕ^​ is tangent to a circle that passes through P P P, is parallel to the x x x– y y y plane, and has a center on the z z z-axis.

  • θ ^ \boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}} θ^ is perpendicular to the plane that contains s ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} s^ and ϕ ^ \boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} ϕ^​.

The relationship between cartesian and spherical coordinates is

x = r sin ⁡ θ cos ⁡ ϕ y = r sin ⁡ θ sin ⁡ ϕ z = r cos ⁡ θ x = r\sin\theta\cos\phi\qquad y = r\sin\theta\sin\phi\qquad z = r\cos\theta x=rsinθcosϕy=rsinθsinϕz=rcosθ

The relationship between cartesian and spherical unit vectors is

r ^ = sin ⁡ θ cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + sin ⁡ θ sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ + cos ⁡ θ z ^ \hat{\mathbf{r}} = \sin\theta\cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \sin\theta\sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}} + \cos\theta\hat{\mathbf{z}} r^=sinθcosϕx^+sinθsinϕy^​+cosθz^

θ ^ = cos ⁡ θ cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ θ sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ − sin ⁡ θ z ^ \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}} = \cos\theta\cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \cos\theta\sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}}-\sin\theta\hat{\mathbf{z}} θ^=cosθcosϕx^+cosθsinϕy^​−sinθz^

ϕ ^ = − sin ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ ϕ y ^ \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} = -\sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}} ϕ^​=−sinϕx^+cosϕy^​

Note that the equation for ϕ ^ \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} ϕ^​ in spherical coordinates is the same as that for cylindrical coordinates.

4.2.2 Problem - Writing Spherical Unit Vectors with Cartesian Coordinates and Unit vectors

Write r ^ \hat{\mathbf{r}} r^ with cartesian coordinates and unit vectors.

4.2.3 Problem - Drawing Spherical Unit Vectors

  1. A = r ^ + θ ^ \mathbf{A} = \hat{\mathbf{r}} + \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}} A=r^+θ^ at the position ( r , θ , ϕ ) = ( 1 , 0 , 0 ) (r,\theta,\phi) = (1,0,0) (r,θ,ϕ)=(1,0,0) and

  2. A = θ ^ \mathbf{A} = \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}} A=θ^ at the position ( r , θ , ϕ ) = ( 1 , π / 2 , π / 2 ) (r,\theta,\phi) = (1,\pi/2,\pi/2) (r,θ,ϕ)=(1,π/2,π/2).

4.2.4 Problem - Computing Spherical Coordinates Given Cartesian Coordinates

Given the position ( x , y , z ) = ( 1 , 1 , 1 ) (x,y,z)=(1,1,1) (x,y,z)=(1,1,1), compute ( r , θ , ϕ ) (r,\theta, \phi) (r,θ,ϕ).

4.3 Deriving

4.3.1 Example - Deriving unit vector relationships with a sketch I

Derive the expression s ^ = cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} = \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}} s^=cosϕx^+sinϕy^​ using a sketch.

Solution: To solve this, we need to compute the cartesian components of s ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} s^. From the sketch, they are s ^ x = cos ⁡ ϕ \hat{s}_x=\cos\phi s^x​=cosϕ and s ^ y = sin ⁡ ϕ \hat{s}_y=\sin\phi s^y​=sinϕ. So, s ^ = cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} = \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}} s^=cosϕx^+sinϕy^​.

Check: From the figure, we expect that when ϕ = 0 \phi=0 ϕ=0, s ^ = x ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}}=\hat{\mathbf{x}} s^=x^ and when ϕ = 9 0 ∘ \phi=90^\circ ϕ=90∘, s ^ = y ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}}=\hat{\mathbf{y}} s^=y^​, both of which are consistent with the answer.

4.3.2 Example - Deriving unit vector relationships with a sketch II

Derive an expression for x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ in terms of cylindrical unit vectors using a sketch.

Solution: To solve this, compute the cylindrical components of x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^. In the figure below on the left, the three relevant unit vectors are shown. On the diagram on the right, the triangle used to compute the components of x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ in the s ^ \mathbf{\hat{s}} s^ and ϕ ^ \boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} ϕ^​ directions is shown. Based on this, x ^ = cos ⁡ ϕ s ^ − sin ⁡ ϕ ϕ ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} = \cos\phi\mathbf{\hat{s}} - \sin\phi\boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} x^=cosϕs^−sinϕϕ^​. Note that the negative sign appears because the component of x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ parallel to ϕ ^ \boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} ϕ^​ is opposite in direction to ϕ ^ \boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} ϕ^​.

Check I: ∣ x ^ ∣ = cos ⁡ 2 ϕ + ( − sin ⁡ ϕ ) 2 = 1 |\hat{\mathbf{x}}|=\sqrt{\cos^2\phi+(-\sin\phi)^2}=1 ∣x^∣=cos2ϕ+(−sinϕ)2​=1, so the answer has unit length.

Check II:

From the diagram on the left, we expect that when ϕ = 0 \phi=0 ϕ=0, x ^ = s ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}}=\hat{\mathbf{s}} x^=s^ and when ϕ = 9 0 ∘ \phi=90^\circ ϕ=90∘, x ^ = − ϕ ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}}=-\boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} x^=−ϕ^​, both of which are consistent with the answer.

Check III

Use the equations

s ^ = cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} = \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}} s^=cosϕx^+sinϕy^​ and ϕ ^ = − sin ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ ϕ y ^ \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} = -\sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}} ϕ^​=−sinϕx^+cosϕy^​

to solve for x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^. Multiply the first equation by cos ⁡ ϕ \cos\phi cosϕ and the second by − sin ⁡ ϕ -\sin\phi −sinϕ and then add the two equations. The result is

cos ⁡ ϕ s ^ − sin ⁡ ϕ ϕ ^ = cos ⁡ ϕ ( cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ ) − sin ⁡ ϕ ( − sin ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ ϕ y ^ ) \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{s}} - \sin\phi\hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} = \cos\phi(\cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}}) - \sin\phi(-\sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}}) cosϕs^−sinϕϕ^​=cosϕ(cosϕx^+sinϕy^​)−sinϕ(−sinϕx^+cosϕy^​)

cos ⁡ ϕ s ^ − sin ⁡ ϕ ϕ ^ = ( cos ⁡ 2 ϕ + sin ⁡ 2 ϕ ) x ^ = x ^ \phantom{\cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{s}} - \sin\phi\hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}}}= (\cos^2\phi + \sin^2\phi)\hat{\mathbf{x}} = \hat{\mathbf{x}} cosϕs^−sinϕϕ^​=(cos2ϕ+sin2ϕ)x^=x^

4.4 Adding

Two vectors that are not written with cartesian unit vectors:

  1. cannot be drawn unless one knows their position because the direction of the unit vectors depends on position and

  2. cannot be added, subtracted, dotted, or crossed unless the positions of the vectors are the same.

The reason is that curvilinear unit vectors depend on position. For example, in cylindrical coordinates, s ^ \mathbf{\hat{s}} s^ and ϕ ^ \boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} ϕ^​ depend on ϕ \phi ϕ according to s ^ = cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} = \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}} s^=cosϕx^+sinϕy^​ and ϕ ^ = − sin ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ ϕ y ^ \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} = -\sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}} ϕ^​=−sinϕx^+cosϕy^​.

This issue is discussed in Griffiths in Section 1.4.1 where he notes that there is a poisonous snake lurking in vectors expressed with curvilinear unit vectors. See also related discussions on StackExchange: 1; 2.

To see that vectors written with cylindrical unit vectors cannot be added in general, consider the vectors

A = 1 s ^ \mathbf{A} = 1\hat{\mathbf{s}} A=1s^ at ( s , ϕ , z ) = ( 1 , 9 0 ∘ , 0 ) (s,\phi,z)=(1,90^{\circ},0) (s,ϕ,z)=(1,90∘,0)

B = 1 s ^ \mathbf{B} = 1\hat{\mathbf{s}} B=1s^ at ( s , ϕ , z ) = ( 1 , 27 0 ∘ , 0 ) (s,\phi,z)=(1,270^{\circ},0) (s,ϕ,z)=(1,270∘,0)

which are skectched below.

Visually, these vectors point in opposite directions and so their sum should be zero. However, straightforward addition gives A + B = 1 s ^ + 1 s ^ = 2 s ^ \mathbf{A}+\mathbf{B}=1\hat{\mathbf{s}} + 1\hat{\mathbf{s}} = 2\hat{\mathbf{s}} A+B=1s^+1s^=2s^, which is incorrect.

To add, subtract, dot, cross, integrate, or differentiate two vectors written with curvilinear unit vectors associated with different points in space, one must first re-write the two vectors with cartesian unit vectors.

At ( s , ϕ , z ) = ( 1 , 0 , 0 ) (s,\phi,z)=(1,0,0) (s,ϕ,z)=(1,0,0), A = 1 s ^ = y ^ \mathbf{A} = 1\hat{\mathbf{s}} = \hat{\mathbf{y}} A=1s^=y^​

At ( s , ϕ , z ) = ( 1 , π , 0 ) (s,\phi,z)=(1,\pi,0) (s,ϕ,z)=(1,π,0), B = 1 s ^ = − y ^ \mathbf{B} = 1\hat{\mathbf{s}} = -\hat{\mathbf{y}} B=1s^=−y^​

so A + B = y ^ − y ^ = 0 \mathbf{A}+\mathbf{B} = \hat{\mathbf{y}} - \hat{\mathbf{y}} = 0 A+B=y^​−y^​=0, which is correct.

4.4.1 Problem - Adding Vectors with Curvilinear Unit Vectors

If A = 1 s ^ \mathbf{A} = 1\hat{\mathbf{s}} A=1s^ at the position ( s , ϕ , z ) = ( 1 , 0 , 0 ) (s,\phi,z) = (1,0,0) (s,ϕ,z)=(1,0,0) and B = 1 s ^ \mathbf{B} = 1\hat{\mathbf{s}} B=1s^ at the position ( s , ϕ , z ) = ( 1 , π / 2 , 0 ) (s,\phi,z) = (1,\pi/2,0) (s,ϕ,z)=(1,π/2,0)

1. Draw A \mathbf{A} A and B \mathbf{B} B and

2. Compute A + B \mathbf{A}+\mathbf{B} A+B.

4.4.2 Problem - Adding Vectors with Curvilinear Unit Vectors

If A = 1 s ^ \mathbf{A} = 1\hat{\mathbf{s}} A=1s^ at the position ( s , ϕ , z ) = ( 1 , 0 , 0 ) (s,\phi,z) = (1,0,0) (s,ϕ,z)=(1,0,0) and B = ϕ ^ \mathbf{B} = \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} B=ϕ^​ at the position ( s , ϕ , z ) = ( 1 , π / 2 , 0 ) (s,\phi,z) = (1,\pi/2,0) (s,ϕ,z)=(1,π/2,0)

1. Draw A \mathbf{A} A and B \mathbf{B} B and

2. Compute A + B \mathbf{A}+\mathbf{B} A+B.

4.5 Integrating

Care is also required when integrating unit vectors. Consider the integral

∫ 0 π / 2 ϕ ^ d ϕ \int_0^{\pi/2} \boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} d\phi ∫0π/2​ϕ^​dϕ

a common error is to factor out the unit vector and conclude

∫ 0 π / 2 ϕ ^ d ϕ = ϕ ^ ∫ 0 π / 2 d ϕ = π 2 ϕ ^ \int_0^{\pi/2} \boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} d\phi =\boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}}\int_0^{\pi/2} d\phi=\frac{\pi}{2}\boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} ∫0π/2​ϕ^​dϕ=ϕ^​∫0π/2​dϕ=2π​ϕ^​

To see why this is wrong, consider a diagram of the vectors being integrated. Each vector has a length of Δ ϕ \Delta\phi Δϕ, and the direction is given by the direction of ϕ ^ \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} ϕ^​.

If one increases the number of vectors and decreases Δ ϕ \Delta \phi Δϕ in the figure, the sum of the vectors becomes and integral. Visually, we expect the integral to be a vector that points upwards and to the left because all of the vectors contributing to the sum are in this direction (except the first and last).

As noted earlier, the addition of vectors expressed with unit vectors in general requires first expressing them with cartesian unit vectors. Integration is a form of addition, and so this rule also applies to integration. Using the relationship ϕ ^ = − sin ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ ϕ y ^ \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} = -\sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}} ϕ^​=−sinϕx^+cosϕy^​, we can write the integrand using cartesian unit vectors

∫ 0 π / 2 ϕ ^ d ϕ = ∫ 0 π / 2 ( − sin ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ ϕ y ^ ) d ϕ \int_0^{\pi/2} \boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} d\phi = \int_0^{\pi/2}(-\sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}})d\phi ∫0π/2​ϕ^​dϕ=∫0π/2​(−sinϕx^+cosϕy^​)dϕ

The cartesian unit vectors do not depend on the coordinate of integration, ϕ \phi ϕ, so they can be factored out, giving

∫ 0 π / 2 ϕ ^ d ϕ = − x ^ ∫ 0 π / 2 sin ⁡ ϕ d ϕ + y ^ ∫ 0 π / 2 cos ⁡ ϕ d ϕ = − x ^ + y ^ \int_0^{\pi/2} \boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} d\phi = -\hat{\mathbf{x}}\int_0^{\pi/2}\sin\phi d\phi + \hat{\mathbf{y}}\int_0^{\pi/2}\cos\phi d\phi = -\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \hat{\mathbf{y}} ∫0π/2​ϕ^​dϕ=−x^∫0π/2​sinϕdϕ+y^​∫0π/2​cosϕdϕ=−x^+y^​

which has the expected direction of upwards and to the left and is consistent with the summation of the small vectors from head to tail as shown in the following figure.

4.5.1 Problem - Integration of Vector with Curvilinear Unit Vectors

Compute

∫ 0 π / 2 s ^ d ϕ \int_0^{\pi/2} \mathbf{\hat{s}} d\phi ∫0π/2​s^dϕ

and use a sketch to show that your answer has the expected direction.

4.5.2 Problem - Integration of Vector with Curvilinear Unit Vectors

Compute

∫ 0 1 s ^ d s \int_0^1 \mathbf{\hat{s}} ds ∫01​s^ds

and use a sketch to show that your answer has the expected direction.

5 Tangent Unit Vectors

5.1 Computing

The general equation for a unit vector that is tangent to the curve y = f ( x ) y=f(x) y=f(x) is

t ^ = x ^ + d y d x y ^ 1 + ( d y d x ) 2 \mathbf{\hat{t}}=\frac{\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \frac{dy}{dx}\hat{\mathbf{y}}}{\sqrt{1 + \left( \frac{dy}{dx}\right)^2}} t^=1+(dxdy​)2​x^+dxdy​y^​​

This equation can be derived using the following figure. At the point shown, the slope of the line is d y / d x dy/dx dy/dx. If we consider a small horizontal displacement of d x dx dx, then a point on the tangent line is given by stepping upwards by the slope times d x dx dx.

To form the tangent vector T \mathbf{T} T, add the horizontal and vertical displacements as vectors

T = d x x ^ + d y d x d x y ^ \mathbf{T} = dx\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \frac{dy}{dx}dx\hat{\mathbf{y}} T=dxx^+dxdy​dxy^​

Dividing T \mathbf{T} T by ∣ T ∣ |\mathbf{T}| ∣T∣ gives a unit vector t ^ = T / ∣ T ∣ \mathbf{\hat{t}}=\mathbf{T}/|\mathbf{T}| t^=T/∣T∣.

Note that there are two unit vectors that are tangent to a given curve. Both t \mathbf{t} t and − t -\mathbf{t} −t are tangent to the curve shown in the previous figure. Generally, you will be given a convention to follow to determine which one to use. In mechanics, the choice will typically depend on the choice of the coordinate system, which determines the direction of positive movement. In E&M, a convention such as the right-hand rule will be used.

For curves in three dimensions, there is a more complex formula for the tangent vector that requires writing the path in parametric form. For the types of problems covered in this course, we will not need this formula.

Unit vectors can also be derived for a surface. However, there are infinitely unit vectors that are tangent to a surface. To narrow the choices, one needs to specify a curve on the surface. As a result, the formula used for computing a vector tangent to a surface is usually the formula for the unit vector that is tangent to a curve in three dimensions.

5.1.1 Example - Computing Tangent Unit Vector

Compute the unit tangent vector to the curve y = 1 + x y = 1+x y=1+x.

t ^ = x ^ + d y d x y ^ 1 + ( d y d x ) 2 \mathbf{\hat{t}}=\frac{\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \frac{dy}{dx}\hat{\mathbf{y}}}{\sqrt{1 + \left( \frac{dy}{dx}\right)^2}} t^=1+(dxdy​)2​x^+dxdy​y^​​

Before computing, write down the expected answer, which for this problem can be computed without using this formula.

Answer: From a sketch of the line, or because the slope of the line is 1 1 1, we expect the unit tangent vector to be at a 4 5 ∘ 45^\circ 45∘ angle, so the x x x– and y y y–components should be equal. Substitution of d y / d x = 1 dy/dx=1 dy/dx=1 into the formula gives t ^ = ( x ^ + y ^ ) / 2 \mathbf{\hat{t}}=(\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \hat{\mathbf{y}})/\sqrt{2} t^=(x^+y^​)/2​.

5.1.2 Problem - Computing Tangent Unit Vector

Compute the unit tangent vector to the curve y = 1 + x 2 y = 1+x^2 y=1+x2. Before computing, write down the expected answer when x = 0 x=0 x=0 and as x → ∞ x\rightarrow \infty x→∞.

5.1.3 Example - Computing Tangent Unit Vector

Show that the tangent unit vector to a circle centered on the origin is ϕ ^ \boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} ϕ^​, which is one of the unit vectors in both cylindrical and spherical coordiinates.

Answer: For y > 0 y > 0 y>0, the equation for a circle is y = 1 − x 2 y = \sqrt{1-x^2} y=1−x2​. After computing the derivative and inserting into the equation for t ^ \mathbf{\hat{t}} t^, you should arrive at t ^ = ( − y x ^ + x y ^ ) / x 2 + y 2 \mathbf{\hat{t}}=(-y\hat{\mathbf{x}}+x\hat{\mathbf{y}})/\sqrt{x^2+y^2} t^=(−yx^+xy^​)/x2+y2​. In cartesian coordinates, x = s cos ⁡ ϕ x=s\cos\phi x=scosϕ and y = s sin ⁡ ϕ y=s\sin\phi y=ssinϕ, and s = x 2 + y 2 s=\sqrt{x^2+y^2} s=x2+y2​. Using these gives t ^ = − sin ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ ϕ y ^ \mathbf{\hat{t}}=-\sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}}+\cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}} t^=−sinϕx^+cosϕy^​, which is the same as the definining formula for ϕ ^ \boldsymbol{\hat{\phi}} ϕ^​ in both cylindrical and spherical coordinates given previously.

5.2 General Use

The most common use of unit tangent vectors is in an integration involving either a force or an electric field (which is proportional to a force). For example, the equation for the work due to a force is

W = ∫ F ⋅ d l = ∫ F ⋅ t ^ d l W=\int \mathbf{F}\boldsymbol{\cdot} d\mathbf{l} = \int \mathbf{F}\boldsymbol{\cdot} \mathbf{\hat{t}} dl W=∫F⋅dl=∫F⋅t^dl

where the relationship d l = t ^ d l d\mathbf{l}=\mathbf{\hat{t}}dl dl=t^dl was used. An alternative way of writing F ⋅ t ^ \mathbf{F}\boldsymbol{\cdot} \mathbf{\hat{t}} F⋅t^ is as F F F with a subscript for “parallel”, F ∥ F_{\parallel} F∥​.

In the following figure, a force acts at an angle to the direction of movement of an object. The force that determines the acceleration in the x x x–direction is F cos ⁡ θ F\cos\theta Fcosθ.

More generally, the force along the direction of movement is F ⋅ t ^ \mathbf{F}\cdot \mathbf{\hat{t}} F⋅t^, where t ^ \mathbf{\hat{t}} t^ is a unit vector in the direction of movement. In the above figure, F = F ( cos ⁡ θ x ^ + sin ⁡ θ y ^ ) \mathbf{F}=F(\cos\theta\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \sin\theta\hat{\mathbf{y}}) F=F(cosθx^+sinθy^​) and t ^ = x ^ \mathbf{\hat{t}}=\hat{\mathbf{x}} t^=x^, so

F ∥ = F ⋅ t ^ = F ( cos ⁡ θ x ^ + sin ⁡ θ y ^ ) ⋅ x ^ = cos ⁡ θ x ^ ⋅ x ^ + sin ⁡ θ y ^ ⋅ x ^ = F cos ⁡ θ F_\parallel = \mathbf{F}\cdot \mathbf{\hat{t}} = F(\cos\theta\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \sin\theta\hat{\mathbf{y}})\boldsymbol{\cdot}\hat{\mathbf{x}} = \cos\theta\hat{\mathbf{x}}\boldsymbol{\cdot}\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \sin\theta\hat{\mathbf{y}}\boldsymbol{\cdot}\hat{\mathbf{x}} = F\cos\theta F∥​=F⋅t^=F(cosθx^+sinθy^​)⋅x^=cosθx^⋅x^+sinθy^​⋅x^=Fcosθ

5.3 Problem

1. Use a diagram to compute the component of F \mathbf{F} F in the direction of movement of the object on a frictionless inclined plane.

2. Write F \mathbf{F} F and t \mathbf{t} t in vector notation an compute the component of F \mathbf{F} F in the direction of movement using F ∥ = F ⋅ t ^ F_\parallel=\mathbf{F}\cdot \mathbf{\hat{t}} F∥​=F⋅t^

Answer:

1. From the following diagram, F ∥ = F cos ⁡ α F_{\parallel}=F\cos\alpha F∥​=Fcosα.

Based on the grid spacing, θ = tan ⁡ − 1 ( 3 / 4 ) \theta=\tan^{-1}(3/4) θ=tan−1(3/4). From the equation for F \mathbf{F} F, F = 13 F o F=\sqrt{13}F_o F=13​Fo​, β = tan ⁡ − 1 ( 3 / 2 ) \beta=\tan^{-1}(3/2) β=tan−1(3/2), and α = β − θ \alpha=\beta-\theta α=β−θ, so

F ∥ = 13 F o cos ⁡ ( β − α ) = 13 F o cos ⁡ [ tan ⁡ − 1 ( 3 / 2 ) − θ = tan ⁡ − 1 ( 3 / 4 ) ] F_\parallel = \sqrt{13}F_o\cos(\beta-\alpha)=\sqrt{13}F_o\cos[\tan^{-1}(3/2)-\theta=\tan^{-1}(3/4)] F∥​=13​Fo​cos(β−α)=13​Fo​cos[tan−1(3/2)−θ=tan−1(3/4)]

2. Based on the grid spacing a vector tangent to the plane is T ^ = 4 x ^ + 3 y ^ \mathbf{\hat{T}}= 4\hat{\mathbf{x}} + 3\hat{\mathbf{y}} T^=4x^+3y^​, so t ^ = ( 4 x ^ + 3 y ^ ) / 5 \mathbf{\hat{t}}=(4\hat{\mathbf{x}} + 3\hat{\mathbf{y}})/5 t^=(4x^+3y^​)/5.

F ∥ = F ⋅ t ^ = ( 2 F o x ^ + 3 F o y ^ ) ⋅ ( 4 x ^ + 3 y ^ ) / 5 = 8 5 F o + 9 5 F o = 17 5 F o \displaystyle F_{\parallel} = \mathbf{F}\cdot \mathbf{\hat{t}} = (2F_o\hat{\mathbf{x}}+3F_o\hat{\mathbf{y}})\boldsymbol{\cdot}(4\hat{\mathbf{x}} + 3\hat{\mathbf{y}})/5=\frac{8}{5}F_o+\frac{9}{5}F_o=\frac{17}{5}F_o F∥​=F⋅t^=(2Fo​x^+3Fo​y^​)⋅(4x^+3y^​)/5=58​Fo​+59​Fo​=517​Fo​

It is left to the reader to confirm that the answer from 1. is the same as the answer to 2 (bonus – do it without a calculator using trig identities).

6 Cross Products

The cross products for cartesian unit vectors are

x ^ × x ^ = 0 y ^ × y ^ = 0 z ^ × z ^ = 0 x ^ × y ^ = z ^ y ^ × z ^ = x ^ z ^ × x ^ = y ^ y ^ × x ^ = − z ^ z ^ × y ^ = − x ^ x ^ × z ^ = − y ^ \begin{aligned} \hat{\mathbf{x}}\times\hat{\mathbf{x}} & = 0 & \hat{\mathbf{y}}\times\hat{\mathbf{y}} & = 0 & \hat{\mathbf{z}}\times\hat{\mathbf{z}} & = 0 \\ \hat{\mathbf{x}}\times\hat{\mathbf{y}} & = \hat{\mathbf{z}} & \hat{\mathbf{y}}\times\hat{\mathbf{z}} & = \hat{\mathbf{x}} & \hat{\mathbf{z}}\times\hat{\mathbf{x}} & = \hat{\mathbf{y}} \\ \hat{\mathbf{y}}\times\hat{\mathbf{x}} & = -\hat{\mathbf{z}} & \hat{\mathbf{z}}\times\hat{\mathbf{y}} & = -\hat{\mathbf{x}} & \hat{\mathbf{x}}\times\hat{\mathbf{z}} & = -\hat{\mathbf{y}} \\ \end{aligned} x^×x^x^×y^​y^​×x^​=0=z^=−z^​y^​×y^​y^​×z^z^×y^​​=0=x^=−x^​z^×z^z^×x^x^×z^​=0=y^​=−y^​​

These can be derived either by using the right-hand rule or a mnemonic (memory) aid for remembering this table. If you do the cross product of two consecutive unit vectors in the order indicated by the arrows in the circle shown in the following figure, the result is the remaining unit vector (the second row in the table).

If you do the cross product of two unit vectors in reverse order, the result is the remaining unit vector with a negative sign (the third row in the table).

For example, in x ^ × y ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}}\times\hat{\mathbf{y}} x^×y^​, to go from x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ to y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^​, your rotate clockwise, so the result is z ^ \hat{\mathbf{z}} z^. In z ^ × y ^ \hat{\mathbf{z}}\times\hat{\mathbf{y}} z^×y^​, you go from z ^ \hat{\mathbf{z}} z^ to y ^ \hat{\mathbf{y}} y^​ by rotating counterclockwise, so the result is − x ^ -\hat{\mathbf{x}} −x^.

The same procedure can be used for cylindrical and spherical unit vectors by using one of the diagrams in the following figure. Note that the order of the unit vectors is the same as one usually writes the coordinates. For example, we typically write ( x , y , z ) (x,y,z) (x,y,z), ( s , ϕ , z ) (s,\phi,z) (s,ϕ,z), and ( r , θ , ϕ ) (r,\theta,\phi) (r,θ,ϕ) when indicating a position in cartesian, cylindrical, and spherical coordinates, respectively.

7 Normal Unit Vectors

7.1 Curve

The general equation for a unit vector that is perpendicular (normal) to the curve y = f ( x ) y=f(x) y=f(x) is

n ^ = − d y d x x ^ + y ^ 1 + ( d y d x ) 2 \mathbf{\hat{n}}=\frac{-\frac{dy}{dx}\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \hat{\mathbf{y}}}{\sqrt{1 + \left( \frac{dy}{dx}\right)^2}} n^=1+(dxdy​)2​−dxdy​x^+y^​​

Similar to the unit tangent vector, there are two unit vectors perpendicular to a curve, n ^ \mathbf{\hat{n}} n^ and − n ^ -\mathbf{\hat{n}} −n^, and the choice of which to use will depend on the choice of coordinate system or the right-hand rule.

A mathematical derivation of n ^ \mathbf{\hat{n}} n^ is to note that we need a vector that satisfies n ^ ⋅ t ^ = 0 \mathbf{\hat{n}}\boldsymbol{\cdot}\mathbf{\hat{t}}=0 n^⋅t^=0 and ∣ n ^ ∣ = 1 |\mathbf{\hat{n}}|=1 ∣n^∣=1. From the dot product and using the notation n ^ = n ^ x x ^ + n ^ y y ^ \mathbf{\hat{n}}=\hat{n}_x\hat{\mathbf{x}}+\hat{n}_y\hat{\mathbf{y}} n^=n^x​x^+n^y​y^​ and t ^ = t ^ x x ^ + t ^ y y ^ \mathbf{\hat{t}}=\hat{t}_x\hat{\mathbf{x}}+\hat{t}_y\hat{\mathbf{y}} t^=t^x​x^+t^y​y^​,

n ^ ⋅ t ^ = 0 = n ^ x t ^ x + n ^ y t ^ y ⇒ n ^ x = − n ^ y t ^ y t ^ x \mathbf{\hat{n}}\boldsymbol{\cdot}\mathbf{\hat{t}}=0=\hat{n}_x\hat{t}_x+\hat{n}_y\hat{t}_y\quad \Rightarrow\quad \hat{n}_x=-\hat{n}_y\frac{\hat{t}_y}{\hat{t}_x} n^⋅t^=0=n^x​t^x​+n^y​t^y​⇒n^x​=−n^y​t^x​t^y​​

Using

t ^ = x ^ + d y d x y ^ 1 + ( d y d x ) 2 \mathbf{\hat{t}}=\frac{\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \frac{dy}{dx}\hat{\mathbf{y}}}{\sqrt{1 + \left( \frac{dy}{dx}\right)^2}} t^=1+(dxdy​)2​x^+dxdy​y^​​

gives

n ^ x = − n y d y d x 1 + ( d y d x ) 2 1 1 + ( d y d x ) 2 ⇒ n ^ x = − n ^ y d y d x ⇒ n ^ = − n ^ y d y d x x ^ + n ^ y y ^ \hat{n}_x=-n_y\frac{ \frac{\frac{dy}{dx}}{\sqrt{1 + \left( \frac{dy}{dx}\right)^2 }}}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + \left( \frac{dy}{dx}\right)^2}}} \quad\Rightarrow\quad \hat{n}_x=-\hat{n}_y\frac{dy}{dx}\quad\Rightarrow\quad \mathbf{\hat{n}}=-\hat{n}_y\frac{dy}{dx}\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \hat{n}_y\hat{\mathbf{y}} n^x​=−ny​1+(dxdy​)2​1​1+(dxdy​)2​dxdy​​​⇒n^x​=−n^y​dxdy​⇒n^=−n^y​dxdy​x^+n^y​y^​

Using ∣ n ^ ∣ = 1 |\mathbf{\hat{n}}|=1 ∣n^∣=1, gives the requirement that n ^ y = 1 / 1 + ( d y d x ) 2 \hat{n}_y=1/\sqrt{1 + \left( \frac{dy}{dx}\right)^2} n^y​=1/1+(dxdy​)2​.

Check I: n ^ ⋅ t ^ \mathbf{\hat{n}}\boldsymbol{\cdot}\mathbf{\hat{t}} n^⋅t^ should be zero.

n ^ ⋅ t ^ = ( − d y d x x ^ + y ^ ) ⋅ ( x ^ + d y d x y ^ ) 1 + ( d y d x ) 2 = − d y d x + d y d x 1 + ( d y d x ) 2 = 0 \mathbf{\hat{n}}\boldsymbol{\cdot}\mathbf{\hat{t}}=\frac{(-\frac{dy}{dx}\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \hat{\mathbf{y}})\boldsymbol{\cdot}(\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \frac{dy}{dx}\hat{\mathbf{y}})}{1+\left( \frac{dy}{dx}\right)^2}=\frac{-\frac{dy}{dx}+\frac{dy}{dx}}{1+\left( \frac{dy}{dx}\right)^2}=0 n^⋅t^=1+(dxdy​)2(−dxdy​x^+y^​)⋅(x^+dxdy​y^​)​=1+(dxdy​)2−dxdy​+dxdy​​=0

Check II: When y = x y=x y=x, we expect the normal vector to point down and to the right or up and to the left (recall that there are two unit vectors normal to a curve at a given point). With y = x y=x y=x, n ^ \mathbf{\hat{n}} n^ is proportional to − x ^ + y ^ -\hat{\mathbf{x}}+\hat{\mathbf{y}} −x^+y^​, which points up and to the left.

In cylindrical coordinates, s ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} s^ and ϕ ^ \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} ϕ^​ are perpendicular and their equations are

s ^ = cos ⁡ ϕ x ^ + sin ⁡ ϕ y ^ ϕ ^ = − sin ⁡ ϕ x ^ + cos ⁡ ϕ y ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} = \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}}\qquad \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} = -\sin\phi\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \cos\phi\hat{\mathbf{y}} s^=cosϕx^+sinϕy^​ϕ^​=−sinϕx^+cosϕy^​

Note that the equation for ϕ ^ \hat{\boldsymbol{\phi}} ϕ^​ is formed by swapping the cos ⁡ ϕ \cos\phi cosϕ and sin ⁡ ϕ \sin\phi sinϕ terms in the equation for s ^ \hat{\mathbf{s}} s^ and adding a negative sign to the x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ term. The equation for n ^ \mathbf{\hat{n}} n^ can also be formed by swapping the terms in the equation for t ^ \mathbf{\hat{t}} t^ and adding a negative sign to the x ^ \hat{\mathbf{x}} x^ term.

7.2 Surface

In E&M, normal (perpendicular) vectors are more often used for surfaces rather than curves. The general equation for a vector perpendicular to a surface is

n ^ = u × v ∣ u × v ∣ \mathbf{\hat{n}} = \frac{\mathbf{u}\times\mathbf{v}}{|\mathbf{u}\times\mathbf{v}|} n^=∣u×v∣u×v​

where u \mathbf{u} u and v \mathbf{v} v are two non–colinear vectors on the surface.

7.2.1 Example

Use the equation for n ^ \mathbf{\hat{n}} n^ to find a normal unit vector for the rectangular surface shown in the following figure.

Answer: Two non–colinear vectors on the surface can be formed by drawing vectors from the corner at the origin to two other corners. These vectors are u = 4 z ^ \mathbf{u}=4\hat{\mathbf{z}} u=4z^ and v = 3 x ^ \mathbf{v}=3\hat{\mathbf{x}} v=3x^.

u × v = 4 z ^ × 3 x ^ = 12 y ^ \mathbf{u}\times\mathbf{v}=4\hat{\mathbf{z}}\times 3\hat{\mathbf{x}}=12\hat{\mathbf{y}} u×v=4z^×3x^=12y^​

n ^ = u × v ∣ u × v ∣ = 12 z ^ ∣ 12 z ^ ∣ = y ^ \mathbf{\hat{n}} = \frac{\mathbf{u}\times\mathbf{v}}{|\mathbf{u}\times\mathbf{v}|}=\frac{12\hat{\mathbf{z}}}{|12\hat{\mathbf{z}}|}=\hat{\mathbf{y}} n^=∣u×v∣u×v​=∣12z^∣12z^​=y^​

as expected. If we had chosen u = 3 x ^ \mathbf{u}=3\hat{\mathbf{x}} u=3x^ and v = 4 z ^ \mathbf{v}=4\hat{\mathbf{z}} v=4z^, the answer would have been − y ^ -\hat{\mathbf{y}} −y^​, which is the other unit vector perpendicular to the surface. We could have also chosen one of the vectors to be the vector that connected the origin to the corner at ( x , y , z ) = ( 3 , 0 , 4 ) (x,y,z)=(3,0,4) (x,y,z)=(3,0,4) and the other to be either 3 x ^ 3\hat{\mathbf{x}} 3x^ or 4 z ^ 4\hat{\mathbf{z}} 4z^.
